;一名澳大利亚水手与他的狗在海上漂流三个月后被墨西哥金枪鱼船救起，他说，自从他们的磨难开始以来，他第一次踏上陆地，他很庆幸自己还活着。

;

;54岁的蒂莫西·林赛·沙多克(Timothy Lyndsay Shaddock)于当地时间周二在墨西哥市曼萨尼约上岸，在救他的船上接受检查后，他下船了，玛丽亚·迪莉娅。

;

;“我感觉很好。我告诉你，我感觉比以前好多了，”在墨西哥城以西约 337 公里（210 英里）的港口城市的码头上，沙多克微笑着说，留着胡须，身材瘦削。

;

;“对于救了我一命的船长和渔业公司，我非常感激。我还活着，但我真的没想到我能活下来，”沙多克说，并补充说他和他的“神奇”狗贝拉都做得很好。

;

;沙多克形容自己是一个安静的人，喜欢独自在海上独处。当被问及为什么四月份从墨西哥巴哈半岛出发，穿越太平洋到达法属波利尼西亚时，他一开始很茫然。

;

;“我不确定我是否能回答这个问题，但我非常喜欢航海，我爱海上的人们，”他说。 “正是海洋人民让我们走到了一起。海洋就在我们身边。我们就是海洋。”

;

;这名悉尼男子的双体船从墨西哥城市拉巴斯起航，但在航行数周后就因恶劣天气而瘫痪。他说他最后一次看到陆地是在五月初，当时他驶出科尔特斯海进入太平洋。那天是满月。

;

;沙多克说他的生活已经很好了，但是一场暴风雨摧毁了他的电子设备和做饭的能力。他和贝拉靠生鱼活了下来。

;

;澳大利亚“漂流者”和狗靠雨水和生鱼在海上生存了两个月

;

;“有很多很多糟糕的日子，也有很多美好的日子，”他说。

;

;“能量和疲劳是最难的部分，”他说。他通过解决问题来打发时间，并通过下水“只是享受在水中的乐趣”来保持积极的态度。

;

;当金枪鱼船上的直升机在距离陆地约 1,930 公里（1,200 英里）处发现沙多克的双体船时，这是他三个月来第一次看到人类的迹象，沙多克说。他说，飞行员给了他一杯饮料，然后飞走了，后来又从玛丽亚·迪莉娅号上乘坐快艇返回。

;

;经营捕鱼船队的格鲁波玛公司没有具体说明救援发生的时间。但该公司在一份声明中表示，沙多克和他的狗被发现时处于“不稳定”状态，缺乏食物和住所，金枪鱼船的船员为他们提供了医疗护理、食物和水。

;

;沙多克说，金枪鱼船成了他的土地，贝拉立即受到了船员们的欢迎。他还解释了他和狗是如何相遇的。

;

;“贝拉在墨西哥中部发现了我。她是墨西哥人，”他说。 “她是这个国家中部的精神，她不会让我走。我三次试图给她找个家，但她一直跟着我到水里。她比我勇敢得多，这是肯定的。”

;

;也许正是因为这个原因，贝拉直到周二沙多克开车离开才离开了船。他已经选择了来自马萨特兰（Mazatlan）的机组人员Genaro Rosales，因为他会照顾好狗的条件。

;

; shaddock说，他将很快返回澳大利亚，他期待着他的家人，并期待他的家人见到他的家人。在太平洋中漂流。他的三名船员死亡。他在夏威夷东南超过 3,220 公里（2,000 英里）处被一艘商船救起。他和其他人当时正在哥伦比亚海岸捕鱼，小船的发动机发生故障，导致他们漂流。

;

;2014 年，一名萨尔瓦多渔民在海上漂流 13 个月后，在马绍尔群岛的太平洋小埃邦环礁上被冲上岸。 2012 年 12 月，何塞·萨尔瓦多·阿尔瓦伦加 (Jose Salvador Alvarenga) 离开墨西哥，去捕捞一天的鲨鱼。他说，他靠鱼、鸟和海龟为生，然后他的船被冲到了 8,850 公里（5,500 英里）外的岸上。

;

;在其他情况下，船只被发现，但没有生还，或者完全失踪。

;

;海豚通常不会攻击人类。据国际移民组织称，除了日本的这个海滩之外，自 2014 年以来，似乎有超过 20,000 名移民在试图穿越地中海前往欧洲时丧生。

;

;Grupomar 总裁安东尼奥·苏亚雷斯 (Antonio Suarez) 周二表示，这可能是“玛丽亚·迪莉娅”号的最后一次旅行，因为他正在对公司船队进行现代化改造，而且这艘船是公司中最小的，而且已有 50 多年的船龄。

;

;苏亚雷斯说，如果是这样，这将是“一次奇妙的告别，拯救了人类的生命”。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 11:20:01 +0800 Singapore unseats Japan as country with world’s most powerful passporthttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3228174/singapore-unseats-japan-country-worlds-most-powerful-passport?utm_source=rss_feed

;根据最新的亨利护照指数，新加坡已取代日本成为世界上最强大的护照，允许免签证进入全球 192 个目的地。

;

;根据总部位于伦敦的移民咨询公司 Henley & Partners 发布的排名，日本在连续五年排名第一后，由于其护照可免签证前往的目的地数量下降，跌至第三位。

;

;近十年前一度位居榜首的美国下滑两位至第八。

;

;英国在脱欧引发的经济衰退后，跃升两位至第四，上次保持这一位置是在 2017 年。

;

;新加坡是一块吸引财富的磁石，最近中国对私营企业的镇压和对地缘政治紧张局势的担忧推动了财富的涌入。

;

;但获得了使用新加坡旅行证件的特权。这并不容易。

;

;随着财富外流，新加坡的百万富翁数量超过了香港

;

;这个拥有 560 万人口的国家去年向约 23,100 人授予公民身份，今年早些时候当局根据个人净资产排除了这样做的可能性。

;

;亨利的排名跟踪了国际航空运输协会的数据。该方法与其他护照指数不同，例如金融咨询公司 Arton Capital 发布的指数，该指数去年将阿拉伯联合酋长国置于领先地位。

;电影导演兼深海探险家詹姆斯·卡梅伦 (James Cameron) 表示，泰坦号潜水器的致命内爆应该促使对载客到海洋深处的船只进行监管，就像一个世纪前泰坦尼克号灾难催生了新的海上安全规则一样。

;

;卡梅伦执导了一部有关沉船的大片，并曾 33 次前往现场，他周二在渥太华告诉记者，这一规则应该针对旅游工艺品，而不是科学或单独任务。他强调，深海勘探界拥有半个世纪的完美安全记录。

;

;“直到今天没有人员伤亡、事故、死亡、内爆，”他说。 “这是一个数据点的极端异常值，从某种意义上说，证明了这一规则。规则是我们半个世纪以来都是安全的。”

;

;卡梅伦站在一艘 24 英尺长、柠檬绿的实验潜水器前发表了上述评论，他于 2012 年驾驶这艘潜水器进入海洋最深处。这艘名为“深海挑战者”号的潜水器正在渥太华参加加拿大皇家地理学会的夏季展览，题为“压力：詹姆斯·卡梅伦陷入深渊”。

;

;发现了“推测的人类遗骸”卡梅伦说，泰坦尼克号灾难导致制定了一项国际安全公约，该公约至今仍适用于商船，要求商船拥有足够的救生艇并规划航程以避免冰山等危险。

;

;加拿大主管表示，确定谁应该领导新法规具有挑战性，因为没有任何一个政府或机构控制进行许多潜水器航行的国际水域。潜在地，每个运营潜水器的政府都必须通过自己的规则。

;

;卡梅伦批评 OceanGate 及其首席执行官斯托克顿·拉什（Stockton Rush 是上个月泰坦号内爆时丧生的人之一）无视专家要求第三方海事安全组织对这艘船进行认证的呼吁。拉什认为这一过程阻碍了创新。

;

;导演自己的深海挑战者号也没有经过认证，但卡梅伦独自一人在狭窄的房间里。他还批评 OceanGate 使用碳纤维船体，称耐压船体应由钢、钛、陶瓷或丙烯酸等材料制成。

;

;他和澳大利亚团队花了七年时间设计了重 11,793 公斤的圆柱形潜水器，该潜水器由一种称为复合泡沫的特殊物质制成，能够承受强大的水下压力。

;

;“在七年的时间里，我非常担心内爆风险和其他危险， “卡梅伦说。 “我们进行了一次又一次的测试和一个又一个的场景。”

;

;卡梅伦在一个大冰箱内进行了 10 到 12 小时的模拟潜水，他的团队会“向他抛出故障”，例如模拟火灾和电池灾难。他说，在这一切之后，他充满信心地进入了这艘船。

;

;卡梅伦周二与他的导师、加拿大海洋探险家兼医生乔·麦金尼斯一起加入，突显了这位电影导演在深海探索界的长期根基。 1968 年，14 岁的卡梅伦写信给麦金尼斯谈论潜水器，两人由此建立了终生的友谊。

;

;导演对上个月在泰坦内爆中丧生的传奇潜水器飞行员保罗-亨利·纳若莱 (Paul-Henri Nargeolet) 表示哀悼。卡梅伦说，两人进行了一场友好的比赛，看看谁跳水最多。

;

;“这是一种情感上的震撼。这就像一记重拳，”他说。 “你不会想到它，因为你没有想到会发生内爆，因为这就是你花费所有时间、所有有限元分析、计算机模拟以及其他一切来防止的事情。”

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 10:50:02 +0800 China steps in with vocational school overhaul and 11 ‘key tasks’ to help boost self-sufficiency and tech prowesshttps://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3228137/china-steps-vocational-school-overhaul-and-11-key-tasks-help-boost-self-sufficiency-and-tech-prowess?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.19 10:00;
;;

;教育部门表示，中国支持和发展职业培训体系的方式需要进行全国性的改革，特别是在战略性行业，因为熟练工程师和蓝领工人的短缺正在阻碍国家的产业升级和经济发展。

;

;为此，教育主管部门发布了一份清单，其中包含 11 项“重点任务”，供地方当局基本用作职业培训之路教育部周一发布的在线声明称，中短期内，地方政府的任务是建立职业学校与工业企业和研究机构的桥梁，以更好地适应市场需求。

;

;教育部表示，“教育部将在先进轨道交通装备、航空航天装备、造船及海洋工程装备、新材料和兵器工业等五个领域设立区域试点项目”。

;

;中国可以吗？ “脱节”的职业体系能否填补蓝领空缺？

;

;该通知多次提到了2025年的一系列目标，但该计划似乎更像是一项开放式、渐进式的任务，具有渐进的里程碑。

;

;它还强调了北京如何介入，不仅创造足够的高技能工人来填补制造业和技术领域的巨大缺口，而且确保他们的学位不会在国家从“中国制造”向“中国制造”转型时浪费。

;

;科学技术进步在应对少子化、人口老龄化问题上也发挥着越来越重要的作用，专家表示，劳动力素质的提高可以在一定程度上弥补人口减少带来的弊端。

;

;工信部表示，还将引导在机械工具、机器人等先进制造业和高技术领域重点行业和领域建立首批产学研一体化共同体。

;

;为了更好适应产业转型和革命，教育系统要加强核心课程、教学设备、师资、数据库、教材等资源建设。

;

;此外，教育部还将引进更多优质教育资源，扩大留学生规模和培养项目，拓宽国际合作。

;

;教育部表示，要“系统打造一批具有中国特色的国际知名职业教育品牌”包括出国教育项目、海外职业技术学院”，以及“培养一批适应国际教学需要的职业教育师资队伍，造就一批服务中国企业海外扩张的本土技术技能人才”。

;

;到2025年，国家计划支持300所左右具有鲜明中国特色的职业学校。

;

;岗位少、工资低：中国职业院校毕业生遭遇现实检验

;

;彭 P省政府智库广东省改革研究会执行会长恩格指出，随着本科层次职业学校的建设越来越多，质量也在不断提高。

;

;“广东华商学院正在与诺贝尔奖获得者合作建立实验室；尤其是广东华立学院，战略性地将校区选址在开发区附近或开发区内，直接服务当地企业。”他说。

;

;“一方面，这些职业院校与市场紧密结合，更容易促进产学研合作。另一方面，它们也在国际合作中经历着转型，尽管这种进展不可能一蹴而就。”

;

;自2016年以来，至少有20个中国支持的职业培训中心（被称为鲁班工坊）在19个国家开设。通过职业培训，中国为制造业、建筑业、农业、科技等各个领域提供技术专长、知识转移和能力建设。

;

;“职业教育对外开放、吸引国外人才相对容易，但中国职业教育走出去则更具挑战性。”一位不愿透露姓名的智库教育权威研究员表示。

;

;“国家正在制定教育强国建设纲要，各部门正在制定详细的发展规划。” ，”他说。 “然而，其中一些计划可能会不经意间落入以口号和陈词滥调的形式追求短期、表面政治成就的陷阱。”

;

;上述领域和行业所需的人才远远超出了技术教育体系所能培养的范围。

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 10:20:02 +0800 Meta makes ChatGPT rival Llama open source as it guns for OpenAI and Google, but it is not trained on Facebook datahttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3228171/meta-makes-chatgpt-rival-llama-open-source-it-guns-openai-and-google-it-not-trained-facebook-data?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.19 10:15;
;;

;Facebook 母公司 Meta Platforms 已经构建了一个人工智能系统，可以与 ChatGPT 和 Google 的 Bard 等产品相媲美，但它采取了不同的方法：免费发布。

;

;Meta 首席执行官马克·扎克伯格 (Mark Zuckerberg) 周二表示，该公司正在与微软合作推出下一代人工智能大型语言模型，并将这项名为 Llama 2 的技术免费用于研究和商业用途。

;

;就像科技同行谷歌和微软一样，这家社交媒体公司长期以来拥有一支由计算机科学家组成的大型研究团队，致力于推进人工智能技术。但随着 ChatGPT 的发布引发了人们热衷于从“生成人工智能”工具中获利，这些工具可以创建新的散文、图像和其他媒体，它的光芒已经黯然失色。

;

;中国电子商务巨头京东推出了自己的大型语言模型 ChatRhino

;

;Meta 还试图通过比一些大型科技竞争对手更加开放的方式来脱颖而出，让人们可以查看其用于构建人工智能系统的数据和代码。它认为，这种开放性使外部研究人员更容易通过吸收真实的人们的写作和交流方式来帮助识别和减轻人工智能系统所产生的偏见和毒性。

;

;“开源推动创新，因为它使更多的开发人员能够使用新技术进行开发，”扎克伯格在周二的 Facebook 帖子中表示。 “它还提高了安全性，因为当软件开放时，更多的人可以仔细检查它以识别和修复潜在问题。我相信，如果生态系统更加开放，将会带来更多进步，这就是我们开源 Llama 2 的原因。”

;

;扎克伯格指出了 Meta 开源其人工智能工作的历史，例如开发了广泛使用的机器学习框架 PyTorch。

;

;但是，介绍新模型的研究论文反映出的开放性不如 Meta 之前在其工作中所表现出的开放性，即构建需要吸收大量数字化作品（例如书籍、新闻文章）的模型。

;

;它表示，最新模型是根据“来自公开来源的新数据组合进行训练的，其中不包括来自 Meta 产品或服务的数据”，但没有具体说明使用了哪些数据。它确实说 Meta 从已知包含“大量有关私人个人信息”的网站中删除了数据。

;

;Meta 使用大型语言模型 Meta AI 的缩写 LLaMA 来描述其 2 月份宣布的模型的第一个版本。现在，它的第二个版本 Llama 2 去掉了大写字母。

;

;扎克伯格表示，人们可以直接下载其新的人工智能模型，也可以通过合作伙伴关系下载其新的人工智能模型，使它们“与微软的安全和内容工具一起”在微软的云平台 Azure 上使用。

;

;该合作伙伴关系的财务条款尚未披露。

;

;虽然 Microsoft 被 Meta 描述为“首选”合作伙伴，但 Meta 表示，这些模型也将通过亚马逊网络服务提供，这是微软的主要的云竞争对手，以及人工智能初创公司 Hugging Face 等。

;

;The four top scorers in Hong Kong's university entrance exams this year came from three traditional elite schools, the Post learned as students on Wednesday morning returned to campuses to receive their results.

;

;Two of the high-fliers came from St Paul's Co-educational College in Central, with one from Good Hope School in Choi Hung and another from Queen's College in Causeway Bay.

;

;Last year, the city recorded 11 top scorers in the Diploma of Secondary Education (DSE) examination, each from a different elite school.

;

;Among the four core subjects this year, the Chinese Language module marked the biggest jump in grades, while the performance for English Language saw the largest decline.

;

;The DSE exam was held between April 21 and May 18 for 48,762 candidates.

;

;4 Hong Kong students bag perfect score in DSE exams, marking record low

;

;Two male and two female pupils scored a perfect 5** on the DSE's seven-level grading scale across all seven subjects this year, the Hong Kong Examinations and Assessment Authority revealed on Tuesday.

;

;Three of those – two boys and a girl – earned 5** for an extended mathematics module elective.

;

;The number of top scorers this year marked a 64 per cent drop compared to 2022.

;

;Wei Xiang-dong, secretary general of the exams body, earlier said the figure was down to “luck”.

;

;“Though there are fewer top scorers, the number of students scoring high marks is not that low compared with last year,” he said, noting that 107 pupils obtained 40 to 42 points compared with 102 in 2022.

;

;“Some students may lack a little luck and could not become top scorers.”

;

;He also noted the total number of candidates obtaining 5* and 5** this year had increased by 0.1 percentage point.

;

;Asked if an emigration wave in the city had resulted in a loss of star pupils, Wei said: “We do not believe the top students have left Hong Kong.”

;Students will be competing for some 12,000 subsidised first-year places via the Joint University Programmes Admissions System (Jupas), a unified mechanism for applying for full-time undergraduate courses, or a ratio of 1.45 eligible students to one slot.

;

;Another 3,000 subsidised places will be given to students applying through a non-Jupas route.

;

;Among the four core subjects, candidates have made the greatest improvement in Chinese Language.

;

;A total of 10.7 per cent candidates scored Level 5 or above, up from 9.5 per cent last year.

;

;Some 58.9 per cent pupils obtained Level 3 or above, the basic requirement to enter public universities, a slight increase from 58.5 per cent last year.

;

;Hong Kong pupils relieved after Diploma of Secondary Education core subject exams end

;Results for the English Language saw the largest decline among all core subjects compared with last year.

;

;Only 9.7 per cent of students scored Level 5 in English Language, down from 10 per cent last year.

;

;Up to 51.6 per cent of students scored Level 3, the basic requirement to enter public universities, in the subject, sliding slightly from 52 per cent last year.

;;

;A woman in Taiwan who thought she was splitting her rent for 10 years with her boyfriend before he ended the relationship has discovered that he was the homeowner and said she was unwittingly used to repay his entire mortgage.

;

;In a post on mainland social media the woman revealed that the couple had been in a relationship for 20 years and rented a flat together after her boyfriend insisted it was more cost-effective than buying property.

;

;The woman said her boyfriend then seemed to instantly find their current flat with three bedrooms and one bathroom with a monthly rent of NT$28,000 (US$900), which they split evenly despite never seeing a lease agreement or any documentation for the rental amount.

;

;She said that she only saw the person she was led to believe was the homeowner once. Whenever something in the flat needed fixing it was done by a tradesperson.

;

;“When I contacted the supposed owner he told me that because he owns multiple properties, he hires external contractors to handle repairs. This is quite common in the rental industry, so I didn't suspect anything,” she said.

;

;Her boyfriend also reassured her by saying: “Our homeowner really values tenant privacy, and he lives far away, so he won't come unless it's necessary.”

;

;The rent payment process was also suspicious in retrospect.

;

;Her boyfriend would give the “owner” the money after she paid her share to him. He also claimed that the owner's address was close to his work, so it was easier for him to deal with him directly and claimed he was worried that the owner might try and date her if she met him.

;

;In the 12th year of their relationship, the woman started a new job that required a much longer commute and proposed moving closer to her work. However, her boyfriend immediately rejected the idea.

;

;“He kept begging me, promising to figure out solutions for commuting long distances. He even offered to drive me to and from work and take care of all household responsibilities,” she said in her post.

;

;The woman added that after 20 years, she thought they were both anticipating getting married. She was wrong.

;

;However, to her surprise, the man suddenly ended their relationship, accused her of being lazy and petty, said they had no future, and told her to move out.

;

;At the same time, a housing loan payment letter addressed to her boyfriend suspiciously arrived at the flat in the mail, and the penny finally dropped that her boyfriend was actually the owner of the flat they had been living in for 10 years.

;

;“It seemed like someone deliberately forwarded the letter. The envelope clearly showed signs of being opened before,” she said.

;

;The monthly mortgage payment was the same amount as her “share” of the rent.

;

;“So I was just paying off his mortgage loan, only to be dumped afterwards,” she added.

;

;Her story has quickly attracted sympathy from online observers, many of whom also offered advice on how she could exercise her legal rights to the property.

;

;“So your boyfriend only paid the down payment and then let you pay the 20-year loan for him?如果您通过银行转账支付租金，仍有机会拿回钱。 But if you gave him cash, I'm sorry to say that you may have to accept the loss,” said one person.

;

;Another person added: “Your boyfriend might have committed fraud.收集证据并咨询律师。 Don't confront your boyfriend yet, it might alert him!”

; Wed, 19 Jul 2023 09:20:03 +0800 Tricked into trafficking? Hong Kong drug mules face uphill fight to prove innocence, with most spending years in prison before releasehttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3228156/tricked-trafficking-hong-kong-drug-mules-face-uphill-fight-prove-innocence-most-spending-years?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;Aminah* and her aunt Sunarti* were shocked when they arrived at Hong Kong International Airport and customs officials used an electric drill to take their suitcases apart.

;

;The Indonesian women were arrested for drug trafficking after the officers found 5kg of crystal meth, commonly known as ice, hidden in the bags

;

;A few weeks before their arrest in June 2019, Aminah, 25, a housewife living in Lombok, had been contacted by her Indonesian friend Kartini* who was working as a domestic worker in Hong Kong.

;

;Drugs seized at Hong Kong airport surged by 80 per cent in first half of year

;

;Kartini said she had befriended a young Nepalese man who was starting a business and needed to bring in materials from Indonesia.

;

;“He was offering US$1,000 per person,” Aminah told the Post. “My aunt was sick and I wanted to use the money to get her treatment in Hong Kong.”

;

;Aminah and Sunarti, 55, agreed to carry two suitcases from Indonesia to Hong Kong, not knowing there were drugs hidden inside.

;

;Aminah's shock at being arrested and detained at the Tai Lam Centre for Women, a maximum-security prison in the New Territories, took a turn when she found out she was pregnant with her first child.

;

;She gave birth to a boy at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in 2020 and was allowed to keep her baby with her in prison.

;

;Number of young people arrested for drugs drops 24 per cent in Hong Kong: police

;

;The two women spent three years in prison awaiting trial, before being acquitted last year because there was enough evidence to convince the judge they had been tricked.

;

;Aminah, her baby and her aunt have since returned to Lombok.

;

;The women are among a minority of those arrested for drug trafficking or smuggling who succeed in persuading the courts that they were tricked, avoiding Hong Kong's stiff penalties of up to a life sentence and a fine of HK$5 million (US$640,000).

;

;Data from Hong Kong customs shows that since the abandonment of Covid-19 travel restrictions, more drugs are being smuggled into the city via the airport.

;

;In the first five months of 2023, about 1,840kg of dangerous drugs worth HK$898 million were seized at the airport, 1.5 times more than over the same period last year.

;

;International drug trafficking syndicates have increased the use of couriers smuggling drugs into Hong Kong, according to the authorities.

;

;During the first six months of 2023, 30 inbound air travellers were arrested on suspicion of smuggling nearly 46kg of narcotics worth HK$39 million. In the whole of 2022, 20 air travellers were detained on smuggling charges.

;

;Aged between 14 and 72, they came from Brazil, Estonia, Ethiopia, Madagascar, Uganda, Mongolia, Denmark and the United States.

;

;Teen drug mule was 15 when caught. Now she's serving 17 years

;

;Father John Wotherspoon, a prison chaplain and chief executive officer of Voice for Prisoners, an NGO that helps people arrested after being duped into trafficking, said he had seen a wide range of tactics used to trick people into carrying drugs.

;

;There were men who tricked their girlfriends after being in long-term relationships, travel agents who offered deals that were too good to be true and online scammers who fooled people into believing they were helping others.

;

;“I would estimate that about 20 per cent of those arrested have been tricked,” said Wotherspoon, 76, a Catholic priest from Australia who has been in Hong Kong for more than 30 years.

;

;“People who have been tricked into becoming drug mules are not criminals or members of drug syndicates, they are innocent victims.”

;

;Over the past eight years, Voice for Prisoners helped 16 people accused of smuggling drugs get acquitted. It is now helping four others whose cases are pending.

;

;Most of those the NGO helped were women. Wotherspoon said single mothers or women in desperate situations tended to be targeted.

;

;For those eventually acquitted, the whole process of gathering evidence to fight the charges took time, which meant sometimes spending years in prison before finally walking free.

;

;The prison chaplain who's stopped 150 drug mules reaching the city

;

;Tricked by 'a good friend'

;

;Malaysian personal assistant Siti*, 51, was caught in June 2018 with 2kg of cocaine hidden in a suitcase after she arrived in Hong Kong from Sao Paulo, Brazil.

;

;She said she was tricked by a Nigerian man she met in Kuala Lumpur and had known for 11 years.

;

;“He was a good friend, he knew my family and would come to our house,” she told the Post.

;

;The man ran a furniture export business in Kuala Lumpur.

;

;“I had done translation work for him, so when he asked me to attend some meetings for him in Sao Paulo and Hong Kong, I agreed,” she said.

;

;When she arrived in Sao Paulo, Siti was told the meeting had been cancelled, but did not suspect anything.

;

;“I stayed in Brazil for three days and was on my way to the airport to go to Hong Kong, when he called from Kuala Lumpur and asked me to help him bring a suitcase of clothes back.”

;

;Customs officers at Hong Kong airport took apart the suitcase and found the narcotics.

;

;Drug dealers use travel perks and quick cash to lure teens into trafficking

;

;By working with her family in Kuala Lumpur, Voice for Prisoners helped collect enough evidence to prove she had been tricked and the jurors at her trial decided unanimously that she was innocent.

;

;The single mother of four was acquitted in December 2020, after being remanded for two years.

;

;Now back in Kuala Lumpur, Siti said she was unable to work because she had to care for her sick mother.

;

;Civil servant Parvati*, an Indian national, was living in Kuala Lumpur when someone she thought was a travel agent offered her an attractive deal on an all-inclusive week-long group tour to Hong Kong in 2019

;

;“When I landed in Hong Kong, a tour guide told me that the group had not arrived yet and I could spend a couple of days in Cambodia for free while I waited,” she said.

;

;“I had nowhere to stay and I was nervous because I'd never left Malaysia before, so I went to Cambodia.”

;

;She was in Phnom Penh for three days with the tour guide. Before leaving for their flight to Hong Kong, he asked if she could help take a bag back for him.

;

;“I started to suspect something,” she recalled. “I kept asking, why do I have to take it?”

;

;She said she asked customs officers in Phnom Penh International Airport to scan the bag twice because she was worried she was being set up, but they found nothing.

;

;City's young smugglers told: your age won't stop you going to jail

;

;“I thought everything was fine after that,” Parvati said. “I was just about to leave Hong Kong airport when customs officers stopped and searched my bag.”

;

;She was arrested after they found 4kg of cocaine, and spent 30 months detained at Tai Lam.

;

;When her case went to court in 2021, her lawyer was able to present text message records between her and those alleged to have tricked her as evidence. The prosecution dropped the case.

;

;'The real criminals get away'

;

;Lawyer Jonathan Midgley, 57, who has defended those accused of smuggling drugs into Hong Kong, recalled a Thai woman who was told she would never see her children again if she did not carry a bag of narcotics to Hong Kong.

;

;“Luckily she was acquitted,” he said.

;

;Criticising the long sentences handed out to mules convicted of drug smuggling, he said: “Mules often get hit with a 20-year sentence, while the people who are behind it rarely get caught.

;

;“The rationale is that punishing mules severely acts as a deterrent but I doubt that it does, because many are tricked or forced to do so under duress.”

;

;During his years of working with prisoners, Wotherspoon has learned of various drug syndicates shipping narcotics into Hong Kong from around the world.

;

;He has travelled to Africa, South America, Malaysia and Thailand to urge syndicate members to stop tricking innocent people into moving drugs.

;

;“I flew out to Sao Paulo in 2018 to find the drug lords there,” he said. “I'd heard that they hung out in a canteen in the slums.”

;

;Hong Kong works with Canada to curb cannabis smuggling at source

;

;Armed with just his travel bag, passport and a cross around his neck, he went to the canteen and began asking for the people he believed were involved in smuggling drugs.

;

;“I approached one group and pleaded with them to stop tricking innocent people into smuggling drugs,” he said.

;

;He recalled what one of them said to him: “If you value your life, you will leave now.”

;

;Wotherspoon said the purpose of his trip was not only to confront drug lords and beg them to stop, which he admitted was unlikely to work, but also to retrace the steps of the people Voice for Prisoners was helping and gather evidence.

;

;He has previously used evidence gained and proof of his interactions with drug syndicates to write letters to judges overseeing cases that have ended in acquittal, most notably in the case of Li Dandan, a Chinese national who was tricked into smuggling 2kg of ice into Hong Kong via Kuala Lumpur.

;

;The woman from Guangzhou was arrested at Hong Kong airport with the drugs in her backpack in 2015. She was acquitted in 2018.

;

;Wotherspoon said it was important to deter people from falling for the tricks of drug smugglers.

;

;To do this, his NGO asks prisoners arrested for smuggling drugs to write letters warning others not to do what they did.

;

;Those who take part in this anti-drug campaign are sometimes offered reductions in their sentences, and the NGO is convinced it has helped discourage many from becoming drug mules.

;

;Jailed for months without trial, then given 48 hours to leave Hong Kong: 6 foreign nationals told 'get out' after drug charges dropped

;

;Syndicates use a variety of methods to get people to carry drugs across borders for them.

;

;Wotherspoon said it was much harder to help suspects caught after swallowing drug-filled pellets concealed in their bodies.

;

;“I have never seen someone in those cases get acquitted, it is too hard to prove that they were forced,” he said.

;

;A spokesman for Hong Kong customs said that in combating cross-boundary drug trafficking, the department had been closely monitoring global and local narcotics trends and adopted effective enforcement tactics.

;

;On June 26, customs officers at the airport stopped a 42-year-old woman who arrived from Kuala Lumpur with 14kg of suspected cocaine found in boxes of agar powder.

;

;Just nine days earlier a 25-year-old woman who arrived from Brazil via Kuala Lumpur was arrested after officers found seven perfume bottles with false compartments used to conceal almost a kilogram of suspected cocaine.

;

;On May 14, a 62-year-old man from the United States, who arrived from Sao Paulo via Paris, was caught with liquid cocaine valued at HK$8 million soaked into 17 bedsheets.

;

;“Swift adjustments on enforcement strategies and resources deployment have been made with a view to stepping up actions against all kinds of drug trafficking activities through different channels,” the spokesman said.

;

;He also said members of the public could report suspected drug trafficking activities to the department's 24-hour hotline (2545 6182) or its dedicated crime-reporting email account (crimereport@customs.gov.hk).

;North Korea launched two ballistic missiles eastward early on Wednesday, Japan's and South Korea's militaries said, just hours after a US ballistic missile submarine arrived in a South Korean port for the first time in four decades.

;

;Both of the missiles appeared to have fallen outside Japan's exclusive economic zone, the Japanese defence ministry said.

;

;South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) called on the North to cease such launches.

;

;“We strongly condemn North Korea's successive ballistic missile launches as grave provocative acts that undermine the peace and stability of the Korean peninsula as well as the international community, and are a clear violation of UN Security Council resolutions,” the JCS said in a statement.

;

;North Korea threatens to shoot down US planes as it condemns nuclear moves

;

;The US military said it was aware of the missile launches and was consulting closely with its allies and partners.

;

;The launches do not appear to pose an immediate threat to the United States or to its allies, but the events highlight the destabilising impact of North Korea's illicit weapons programme, the US Indo-Pacific Command said in a statement.

;

;The first missile reached an altitude of 50km (31 miles) and covered a range of 550km, while the second one rose as high as 50km and flew 600km, Japanese Defence Minister Yasukazu Hamada told reporters.

;

;Japan lodged a protest against the missile launches through diplomatic channels, he said.

;

;The firing comes nearly a week after North Korea tested its latest Hwasong-18 intercontinental ballistic missile, a launch Pyongyang said was a warning to the United States and other adversaries.

;

;Also on Tuesday, a US soldier facing disciplinary action fled across the inter-Korean border into North Korea. The soldier is believed to be in North Korean custody, Washington said, creating a fresh crisis between the two foes.

;

;“North Korea's latest firing of ballistic missiles is probably unrelated to an American soldier crossing the inter-Korean border, but such an incident doesn't help matters either,” said Leif-Eric Easley, a professor at Ewha University in Seoul.

;

;North Korea “undoubtedly opposes” a new US-South Korea nuclear war planning group that met for the first time on Tuesday, as well as the visit of the US nuclear ballistic missile submarine, he said.
